awd_titl_txt: CPS: Synergy: Collaborative Research:  Coordinated Resource Management of Cyber-Physical-Social Power Systems
awd_abstract_narration:
Large-scale critical infrastructure systems, including energy and transportation networks, comprise millions of individual elements (human, software and hardware) whose actions may be inconsequential in isolation but profoundly important in aggregate. The focus of this project is on the coordination of these elements via ubiquitous sensing, communications, computation, and control, with an emphasis on the electric grid. The project integrates ideas from economics and behavioral science into frameworks grounded in control theory and power systems. Our central construct is that of a ?resource cluster,? a collection of distributed resources (ex: solar PV, storage, deferrable loads) that can be coordinated to efficiently and reliably offer services (ex: power delivery) in the face of uncertainty (ex: PV output, consumer behavior). Three topic areas form the core of the project: (a) the theoretical foundations for the ?cluster manager? concept and complementary tools to characterize the capabilities of a resource cluster; (b) centralized resource coordination strategies that span multiple time scales via innovations in stochastic optimal control theory; and (c) decentralized coordination strategies based on cluster manager incentives and built upon foundations of non-cooperative dynamic game theory.

These innovations will improve the operation of infrastructure systems via a cyber-physical-social approach to the problem of resource allocation in complex infrastructures. By transforming the role of humans from passive resource recipients to active participants in the electric power system, the project will facilitate energy security for the nation, and climate change mitigation. The project will also engage K-12 students through lab-visits and lectures; address the undergraduate demand for power systems training through curricular innovations at the intersection of cyber-systems engineering and physical power systems; and equip graduate students with the multi-disciplinary training in power systems, communications, control, optimization and economics to become leaders in innovation.

por.por_cntn:
The overall goal of this project was to study some major technical problems in modern power systems that arise from challenges posed by integration of renewable sources of electric energy such as solar and wind generators. These sources are inherently variable, uncertain, and largely uncontrollable. These features distinguish them from traditional sources such as fossil-fuel, nuclear, and hydroelectric generators. In addition, there is compelling need to reduce the peak electric power demand as that has a direct beneficial impact of reducing the need for new capital investments in overall power sector.

One of our major findings was on the approach that exploits the inherent flexibility in many types of electric power loads and use that to accommodate the inherent variability in renewable generation and/or to reduce the peak demand. A simple example of such loads is an electric vehicle (EV). As numbers of flexible loads are potentially very large, it is important to create and analyze distributed algorithms to compute solutions. We obtained very fundamental mathematical results on the performance of distributed and decentralized optimization of flexible loads. These results will be among the foundations for the future development of control algorithms for flexible loads.

Reducing the carbon footprint of data centers is becoming a significant goal of large IT companies. How to better utilize the green energy from renewable sources in data centers is a challenging problem. We showed how to exploit the opportunities offered by geographical load balancing, opportunistic scheduling of computational workloads, and thermal storage management in data centers to facilitate green energy integration and reduce the cost of brown energy usage. An online control algorithm was proposed to solve it. The algorithm can enable an explicit trade-off between cost saving and workload delay. 

We also investigated the scheduling of flexible electric loads in a smart grid so as to minimize peak power demand. Specifically, we focused on the case when the loads are “preemptable”, (e.g., can be interrupted and then resumed again), their power requirement and duration are known in advance, and they have the same earliest start time and the same deadline. Electric vehicle charging is an example of such loads. Our main results showed that when power requests are scheduled preemptively, the peak power demand can be reduced by up to 50% relative to when these requests are scheduled non-preemptively. We also constructed computational algorithms for scheduling such loads to  minimize peak power demand.

Due to the inherent variability and uncertainty of renewable energy resources such as wind and solar energy, their insertion into the connected power system imposes additional integration costs on the system. Allocating the costs generated by the variable resources is thus crucial for economic efficiency. We developed an axiomatic framework using the cost causation based principle. The cost causation principle has a long historical tradition in electrical systems and has been proved to provide economic efficiency. We applied our cost causation based framework to allocate the cost in the production deviation of a group of renewable energy producers and therefore promote the market integration of renewable energy.

It is well-known in the behavioral economics field that human decision makers sometimes do not make the optimal choice that would optimize their payoff function. In price/market based approaches, consumers of flexible loads optimize their consumption schedules to meet their energy/power demands while minimizing their total costs. However, it may be that not all consumers will optimize their consumption schedules. In this project, we analyzed and showed that the optimal utility derived by a rational consumer may be lower than the case when all consumers act rationally.

We investigated the idea of aggregation of renewable energy since it has significant potential to mitigate undesirable characteristics such as intermittency and variability. We demonstrated that aggregation is also beneficial for renewable energy producers because they can increase their expected profit by making a coalition, bidding a joint contract in the electricity market that maximizes the expected profit and sharing the profit in a way that keeps the aggregation stable.

Broader Impacts Activities:

PI Khargonekar taught a graduate level course on a Smart Grid: Smart Grid: A Cyber-Physical Systems Approach at the University of Florida. This was among the very first such courses on cyber-physical systems approach to smart grid. Since that time, he has refined the course materials and has shared the course materials with faculty members from other universities across the nation. He also involved and mentored a woman engineering student when she was a freshman in electrical and computer engineering in this research project. She has since completed her BS degree and is now pursuing a PhD at Berkeley.
